pullRequest.body:
This PR defines `Sheaf.Œì : Sheaf J A ‚•§ A` as the functor taking each sheaf to the limit of its underlying presheaf whenever possible, i.e. whenever `A` has sufficiently large limits, and shows that this agrees with several other common definitions when they are defined, like evaluation of sheaves on a terminal object. See [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/116395-maths/topic/global.20sections.20functor) for the discussion that lead to this approach.

---

My goal with this PR is to work towards the cohesive structure of sheaves on cohesive sites; I have already defined local sites [here](https://github.com/peabrainiac/lean-orbifolds/blob/main/Orbifolds/ForMathlib/LocalSite.lean) as a stepping stone and will PR them too shortly.

The main thing I am unsure about here is where to place the prerequisite lemmas that do not involve `Sheaf.Œì` already; for `limNatIsoSectionsFunctor ` and `sheafSectionsNatIsoEvaluation` I think I have found good homes, and `terminalObjIso` could be placed in `Limits.FunctorCategory.Shapes.Products` too with only a minor increase in imports, but for `sectionsFunctorNatIsoCoyoneda` I have not been able to find a good home other than the global sections file itself. I suppose we could just leave it there, but maybe someone else has a better idea.

Thanks for your review and explanation of why this extra generality is actually important / useful. I've rewritten this in terms of `HasGlobalSectionsFunctor` now like you suggested, and also added `Sheaf.ŒìNatIsoLim` to show that this is equivalent to the previous definition when `A` has the right limits. I didn't go through the route via `Sheaf.ŒìHomEquiv` that you outlined yet, but can also try implementing that tomorrow (I just wanted to get this refactor pushed first).

One slightly annoying thing I noticed is that with this new definition, `Sheaf.Œì` now requires `HasWeakSheafify`, which [`instHasSheafifyOfHasFiniteLimits`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Sites/LeftExact.html#CategoryTheory.instHasSheafifyOfHasFiniteLimits) only seems to provide for `Type max u v` but not higher universe levels like `Type max u v w`; at least I couldn't get it to work with the latter, and so had to remove `w` from the last few lemmas in the file. In the cases I am most interested in `u` and `v` are both 0, so this is quite a loss of generality. This does seem more like an issue with the instance than a mathematical issue to me though, so hopefully it can be resolved with another PR.
Oh, also this seems like just a general lemma about `Functor.flip` - do we want that in its general form? Or do we maybe even have it already, and I just couldn't find it?

This should be first stated as an equivalence of types for each sheaf (with more general universes, the LHS and RHS will be in different universes), followed by a naturality lemma, and then it can be stated as a natural isomorphism when the universes match.

> This should be first stated as an equivalence of types for each sheaf (with more general universes, the LHS and RHS will be in different universes), followed by a naturality lemma, and then it can be stated as a natural isomorphism when the universes match.

I'm unsure about what exactly you're suggesting - should all the natural isomorphisms here be stated in terms of isomorphisms/equivalences first, or is there some special reason to do it specifically with this one? I would have thought that isomorphisms involving `Œì` are particularly bad candidates for a more step-by-step API like this, since `Œì` is now defined simply as a right-adjoint and not really constructed anyways.
I am referring only to natural "isomorphisms" between functors to types, where the target types may live in different universes, which happens here when universes are left completely general.

Unfortunately, I doubt that the interesting cases in algebraic geometry where there is a global section functor but no terminal object are covered by these assumptions. Sites in algebraic geometry tend to be large, and we may have a small family of objects which cover the terminal object even though we may not have limits indexed by `C·µí·µñ`. It means that we would probably have to refactor this definition in the future. This is part of the reason why I had suggested another design where we define the global sections by taking a right adjoint of the constant sheaf functor. I have just drafted the following (which also takes advantage of the already known results about the constant sheaf functor, see the file `Sites.ConstantSheaf`), and it does not seem to be difficult to obtain the same results which you obtained with the other definition:

```lean
variable [HasWeakSheafify J A]

abbrev HasGlobalSectionsFunctor := (constantSheaf J A).IsLeftAdjoint

instance hasGlobalSectionsFunctor_of_hasTerminal [HasTerminal C] :
    HasGlobalSectionsFunctor J A :=
  ‚ü®_, ‚ü®constantSheafAdj J A terminalIsTerminal‚ü©‚ü©

section

variable [HasGlobalSectionsFunctor J A]

noncomputable def Sheaf.Œì : Sheaf J A ‚•§ A :=
  (constantSheaf J A).rightAdjoint

/-- The constant sheaf functor is left-adjoint to the global sections functor when both exist. -/
noncomputable def constantSheafŒìAdj :
    constantSheaf J A ‚ä£ Œì J A :=
  Adjunction.ofIsLeftAdjoint (constantSheaf J A)

instance : (constantSheaf J A).IsLeftAdjoint :=
  ‚ü®Œì J A, ‚ü®constantSheafŒìAdj J A‚ü©‚ü©

instance : (Œì J A).IsRightAdjoint :=
  ‚ü®constantSheaf J A, ‚ü®constantSheafŒìAdj J A‚ü©‚ü©

variable {J A}

noncomputable def Sheaf.ŒìHomEquiv {X : A} {F : Sheaf J A} :
    ((Functor.const _).obj X ‚ü∂ F.val) ‚âÉ (X ‚ü∂ (Œì J A).obj F) :=
  ((sheafificationAdjunction J A).homEquiv _ _).symm.trans
    ((constantSheafŒìAdj J A).homEquiv _ _)

@[simps pt]
noncomputable def Sheaf.coneŒì (F : Sheaf J A) : Cone F.val where
  pt := (Œì J A).obj F
  œÄ := ŒìHomEquiv.symm (ùüô _)

def Sheaf.isLimitConeŒì (F : Sheaf J A) : IsLimit F.coneŒì := by
  -- should be easy from `ŒìHomEquiv` and a few naturality lemmas
  sorry

noncomputable def Sheaf.Œìres (F : Sheaf J A) (U : C·µí·µñ) :
  (Œì J A).obj F ‚ü∂ F.val.obj U := F.coneŒì.œÄ.app U

@[reassoc (attr := simp)]
lemma Sheaf.Œìres_map (F : Sheaf J A) {V U : C·µí·µñ} (f : U ‚ü∂ V) :
    F.Œìres U ‚â´ F.val.map f = F.Œìres V :=
  F.coneŒì.w f

@[simp]
lemma Sheaf.coneŒì_œÄ_app (F : Sheaf J A) (U : C·µí·µñ) : F.coneŒì.œÄ.app U = F.Œìres U := rfl

noncomputable def Sheaf.ŒìNatIsoSheafSections {T : C}
    (hT : IsTerminal T) : Œì J A ‚âÖ (sheafSections J A).obj (op T) :=
  Adjunction.rightAdjointUniq (constantSheafŒìAdj J A) (constantSheafAdj J A hT)

end
```

```suggestion
@[simps!]
def sheafSectionsNatIsoEvaluation {X : C} :
    (sheafSections J A).obj (op X) ‚âÖ sheafToPresheaf J A ‚ãô (evaluation _ _).obj (op X) :=
  NatIso.ofComponents (fun _ ‚Ü¶ Iso.refl _)
```
